bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Frank R. McCoy, January 11, 1932

div1.p: Kean congratulates McCoy on his appointment to Manchuria and comments on Hagedorn's biography of Leonard Wood.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Frank R. McCoy, January 11, 1932
div1.opener:
11 January, 1932.
Major General Frank R. McCoy, USA.,
Fort McPherson, Ga.
My dear McCoy:
div1.p:
I am so glad to know that the President has selected you
to go to Manchuria. There is no one who could look after our interest
there better than you and no one who enjoys being on the stage where
history is being made as you do. This is just a line of congratula-
tion if it catches you before you get off. I know when you get orders
of this sort, you do not let the grass grow under your feet.

Did I send you my review of The Martial Spirit by Walter
Millis? It peeved me greatly and it has all come back to me since
I have been reading Hagedorn's Life of General Wood. It shows what
an ass Millis is to speak of General Wood as “a colorless type”. Can
you imagine an adjective that was more inappropriate? I am enjoying
greatly living over the old days in retrospect as I read Hagedorn's
biography though I do thinkknow that it is in such a laudatory strain, not
that I object at all to his saying all the nice things about General
Wood but it certainly injures the effect of the book to have such an
unbroken song of hero worship. I am enclosing my review of The Martial
Spirit which you can throw away after reading, and do not trouble
yourself to answer this note.

I am wondering whether Mrs. McCoy will go with you. I
suppose she could be very comfortable and happy at Tientsin.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, J. R. KEAN
Brig. Gen. U.S. Army, Ret.,
Editor. jrk/w
